projectDesc.p: To the tune “Strike the Parasol Tree”—"Her deep dimples are fragrantly powdered" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the tune “Strike the Parasol Tree”
Her deep dimples are fragrantly powdered,
her posture is enchanting;
she is gifted with elegance and extraordinary beauty.
Ever since I met her,
I have been treated with care,
and so I knew her bewitching heart (was devoted to me).

Upon parting, we swore to share joy again
A euphemism for sex.,
and promised our lives to each other.
I am still afraid that our love
will be easily broken and hard to keep.
I cannot help but have a thousand thoughts and worries.
Recently, her letter came
with only simple greetings.
There are no words of sorrow or earnest concern at all.
Thus, I am sure that
she must have listened to others
and plans to throw away her previous promises.

I have heard of Song Yu of the Orchid Terrace
See discussion in introduction.,
who was very talented and excelled in songs and rhapsodies.
I’d like to ask him,
every morning and every night,

where did the floating cloud go
See introduction for a discussion of these two lines.?
